text: <@U1P1ZV6RF> the REST API is deprecated, and not in the mainstream of testing. Suggest that you use the Node SDK to interact with the peer network (deploying, invoking, querying chaincode) or use the 'peer chaincode’ CLI commands.

I am trying to deploy example02 chaincode through CLI commands instead of REST API and since I activated security, in order to do so I need to provide a user name (-u switch). When I do it, I receive an output that I need to perform peer network login <username> in order to obtain a security token. When I try doing this I receive the following error
currently my network is working at 172.17.0.x
so I assume I need to add a switch to the command but --help does not help me much here
<@U1P1ZV6RF> - what's the output of `ss -l |grep 7051`
there is no output
but this is weird
my network is operational
<@U1P1ZV6RF|matanyahu> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/matanyahu/F2FH7633K/selection_073.png|Selection_073.png>
curl shows that the network is operational

vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.1.0-3cfaeb5:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example02$ curl 172.17.0.3:7050/chain/blocks/0
{"nonHashData":{"localLedgerCommitTimestamp":{"seconds":1474672553,"nanos":659993002}}}
try  `CORE_PEER_ENDPOINT=172.17.0.3:7051 peer network login admin`
it still tried to connect through the default address
whoa! <@U0KPFAZNF> nice work on the refactor of baseimage and vagrant… now lightning fast
I haven’t tried it but will soon, thanks <@U0KPFAZNF> !
Ty, though to be fair, I'm cheating a little by not building "make peer" any more
Quick question: when I run "peer node start --peer-chaincodedev", a practical effect is an execution of a single VP with NOOPS consensus?
I think it depends on your config
I am following instructions as per <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Setup/Chaincode-setup/#running-the-chaincode>
I'm not familiar with the --peer-chancodedev (haven't seen in in the code, it was added at some point I think) but the consensus algorithm and others are determined via the config file, core.yaml
there you can specify whats the algorithm. at least that's what was a few months ago, unless it has changed
although I reconfigured core.yaml to launch pbft consensus, the abovementioned command only launches a single peer which obviously selects noops as default
that's my logical understanding of things
why? N=1, f=0
the conditions for PBFT is N >= 3f+1
you can verify in the logs
it says what algorithm it selected when the peer starts
<@U1P1ZV6RF> devmode defaults to noops
I am still struggling to perform peer network login <username> to the network that I launched through docker-compose -f docker-compose-4-consensus-batch.yml
currently, the network is running with following network configuraiton
curl works fine
but whatever actions I want to perform and which require token retrieval (like chaincode deployment), the operation fails
I tried to call a specific ip address of a peer but with the same result
and this is what happens when I try to deploy chaincode

vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.1.0-3cfaeb5:~$ peer chaincode deploy -u jim -p <http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example02|github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example02> -c '{"Function":"init", "Args": ["a","100", "b", "200"]}'
Error: User 'jim' not logged in. Use the 'peer network login' command to obtain a security token.

oops - I think I gave you the wrong info: 
`CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=172.17.0.3:7051 peer network login admin`
weird

text: so, to summarize, when I do CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=172.17.0.x:7051 peer network login <USERNAME> I either receive a fatal error from one of peers (172.17.0.3) or a wrong token/pwd from remaining peers (which is not true, I extract these from membersrvc.yml). I restarted the network, to no avail.
Any ideas what alternative ways could I use to deploy chaincode in such configuration?
and if the above is an intended functioning?
